questions.text: Methemoglobinemia is associated with which local anaesthetic drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prilocaine

 

Methemoglobinemia is associated with certain local anesthetic drugs, and one of those drugs is:

 

Option B.

 

  • Prilocaine is a local anesthetic commonly used for various medical and dental procedures.
  • One of its potential side effects is the development of methemoglobinemia.
  • Methemoglobinemia is a condition where hemoglobin in the blood is oxidized and unable to carry oxygen effectively, leading to reduced oxygen delivery to tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Articaine and benzocaine are also local anesthetics that can cause methemoglobinemia.
  • Methemoglobinemia can lead to symptoms such as cyanosis (bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes), shortness of breath, dizziness, and altered mental status.
  • Treatment of methemoglobinemia often involves administering methylene blue, which helps convert methemoglobin back to its normal, oxygen-carrying form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methemoglobinemia is a rare but serious side effect associated with certain local anesthetic drugs, including prilocaine, articaine, and benzocaine.

 

METHEMOGLOBINEMIA

 

It is characterized by

 

  • Reduced haemoglobin >1 g/dL in RBCs.
  • Blood turns chocolate-brown in colour
  • Postmortem Lividity – Chocolate brown

 

Causes –

 

  • Prilocaine, Benzocaine
  • Nitrates/Nitrites
  • Aniline
  • Dapsone, Sulfonamides

 

Treatment –

 

  • DOC – I.V Methylene Blue
  • Vitamin C can be used as an ancillary treatment.

 

Important information about local anesthestics:-

 

  • Chlorprocaine is the shortest acting LA.
  • Dibucaine is the longest acting, most potent and most toxic LA.
  • Bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic LA
  • Levobupivacaine (the S (-) enantiomer of bupivacaine) is less cardiotoxic and less prone to cause seizure.
  • Lignocaine is the most commonly used LA.
  • Chlorprocaine is contraindicated in spinal anaesthesia as it can cause paraplegia due to presence of neurotoxic preservative sodium metabisulphite.
  • Procaine is the LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesiology 7th edition pg 491

questions.text: Local anaesthetics have greatest affinity for which type of sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inactivated

 

Option B.

 

  • Sodium channels in the inactivated state are a preferred target for local anesthetics.
  • Local anesthetics have the greatest affinity for sodium channels when they are in this state, which occurs shortly after the channel has been activated and has closed in response to the depolarization of the cell membrane.
  • Binding to inactivated sodium channels prevents them from reopening, thus inhibiting the generation and propagation of action potentials.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Activated:

 

  • Sodium channels can exist in an activated state when they are open, allowing the influx of sodium ions during an action potential.
  • Local anesthetics do interact with sodium channels, but their binding affinity is not highest when the channels are in the activated state.

 

Option C. Resting:

 

  • Sodium channels in the resting state (closed) are not the primary target for local anesthetics.
  • These channels are not actively involved in the generation of action potentials, and local anesthetics are more effective at blocking channels in the inactivated state.

 

Option D. Open:

 

  • Sodium channels in the open state allow the flow of sodium ions, and they are not the primary target for local anesthetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Local anesthetics exert their effects by blocking sodium channels in the inactivated state. This is a crucial mechanism of action as it prevents the generation and propagation of action potentials in neurons, leading to the loss of sensation in the region where the local anesthetic is applied.

 

 

Local anaesthetics have maximum affinity for Na+ channels in inactivated state as compared to resting or open state. They bind to the Na+ channels from inside and block them due to which the action potential cannot be generated, and impulse cannot be propagated.

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 9th edition pg 866

questions.text: You want to give a brachial plexus block for open reduction internal fixation of fracture of distal end radius. In order to improve the speed of onset and depth of blockade, which of these additives should be added to the local anesthetic solution?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Sodium Bicarbonate

 

Option D.

 

  • Sodium bicarbonate is added to local anesthetic solutions to increase the pH of the solution, making it more alkaline.
  • Alkalization of the solution enhances the fraction of lipid-soluble local anesthetic that is available, aiding in the diffusion of the drug across the lipid membranes of the nerves.
  • This results in a faster onset of anesthesia and a deeper level of blockade.
  • It also reduces the required dosage of local anesthetic, lowering the risk of systemic toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Adrenaline:

 

  • Adrenaline (epinephrine) is often added to local anesthetic solutions to prolong the duration of the block by vasoconstriction, which reduces the systemic absorption of the local anesthetic.
  • While adrenaline is valuable for prolonging the block, it does not enhance the speed of onset or depth of blockade.

 

Option B. Fentanyl:

 

  • Fentanyl is an opioid analgesic and is not typically added to local anesthetic solutions for regional blocks.
  • It can provide pain relief but does not affect the onset or depth of the block.

 

Option C. Sodium Carbonate:

 

  • Sodium carbonate is not commonly used as an additive to local anesthetic solutions for regional blocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The addition of sodium bicarbonate to a local anesthetic solution for a brachial plexus block is a valuable technique to improve the speed of onset and depth of blockade. Alkalizing the solution enhances the availability of lipid-soluble local anesthetic, facilitating its diffusion across nerve membranes. This not only results in a more effective blockade but also reduces the required dose of local anesthetic, decreasing the risk of systemic toxicity.

 

 

Ref: Stoelting's Pharmacology and Physiology in Anesthesia Practice, 5th Edition, Page no -291

Potassium Channel Blockade
Calcium Channel Blockade

questions.text: Which of these is the main action of local anaesthetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sodium Channel Blockade

 

Option A.

 

  • The primary mechanism of action of local anesthetics is the blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels in nerves.
  • By blocking these sodium channels, local anesthetics prevent the influx of sodium ions and the generation of action potentials in nerve fibers, leading to reversible loss of sensation in the affected area.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. NMDA Antagonism:

 

  • While local anesthetics primarily act on sodium channels, some may have additional actions, such as NMDA receptor antagonism.
  • NMDA receptors are involved in the perception of pain and the transmission of pain signals in the central nervous system.
  • NMDA antagonism may contribute to the analgesic effects of certain local anesthetics.

 

Option C. Potassium Channel Blockade:

 

  • Local anesthetics do not typically block potassium channels as their primary mode of action. The primary target is sodium channels.

 

Option D. Calcium Channel Blockade:

 

  • Local anesthetics do not primarily block calcium channels. They primarily target sodium channels to achieve their anesthetic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

The main action of local anesthetics is the blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels in nerves. This blockade prevents the generation and propagation of action potentials, resulting in reversible loss of sensation in the affected area. While some local anesthetics may have additional actions, such as NMDA antagonism, their primary mechanism of action is sodium channel blockade.

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition page 1038

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is posted for bone marrow biopsy under GA. You put EMLA cream on his hand to facilitate IV-line insertion. What is the contact time required with the skin for the cream to have action?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 60 min

 

Option C. The recommended contact time for EMLA cream to achieve its maximum action on intact skin is 60 minutes. This duration allows for the proper absorption and onset of the local anesthetic effect.

 

Explanation:-

 

EMLA cream, which stands for "Eutectic Mixture of Local Anesthetics," is a topical anesthetic cream that consists of a 1:1 mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. It is commonly used to provide local analgesia when applied to the skin or mucous membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EMLA cream, a eutectic mixture of local anesthetics, is used for providing local analgesia when applied to the skin or mucous membranes. To achieve its maximum action on intact skin, EMLA cream should be left in contact with the skin for a duration of 60 minutes.

 

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition pg 488

questions.text: All of the following local anesthetics are metabolized in the plasma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cocaine

 

Option B.

 

  • Cocaine is a unique local anesthetic in that it is primarily metabolized (ester hydrolysis) in the liver, not in the plasma.
  • Liver enzymes, particularly carboxylesterases, play a crucial role in the metabolism of cocaine into various metabolites.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Procaine:

 

  • Procaine is an ester local anesthetic that is primarily metabolized by pseudocholinesterase (also known as butyrylcholinesterase) in the plasma.
  • Ester hydrolysis of procaine occurs rapidly, leading to the formation of water-soluble metabolites that are excreted in the urine.

 

Option C. Tetracaine:

 

  • Tetracaine is another local anesthetic that is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase in the plasma, similar to procaine.
  • Ester hydrolysis of tetracaine leads to the formation of metabolites that are excreted in the urine.

 

Option D. Benzocaine:

 

  • Benzocaine, like procaine, is an ester local anesthetic that is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase in the plasma.
  • Ester hydrolysis of benzocaine results in the formation of p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) as a metabolite, which has been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Local anesthetics can be categorized into ester and amide types, and their metabolism varies between these categories. Ester local anesthetics, such as procaine, tetracaine, and benzocaine, are predominantly metabolized by pseudocholinesterase in the plasma, with rapid ester hydrolysis leading to water-soluble metabolites excreted in the urine. Ester hydrolysis is rapid, and the water-soluble metabolites are excreted in the urine.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition pg 269 Morgan 7th 490

questions.text: Identify the block given in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bier’s Block

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Bier's Block

 

Bier's block, also known as Intravenous Regional Anesthesia, is a technique used to provide surgical anesthesia for relatively short and superficial surgical procedures on an extremity, such as carpal tunnel release. The key features of Bier's block include the use of an intravenous catheter inserted into the dorsum of the hand (or foot) and the application of a double pneumatic tourniquet on the forearm, arm, below the knee, or on the thigh. Local anesthetic is then injected through the intravenous line into the isolated extremity.

 

  • Lidocaine is commonly used as the local anesthetic agent for intravenous regional anesthesia (Bier's block).
  • Bupivacaine and Ropivacaine are contraindicated for use in Bier's block due to the potential for cardiac toxicity with these agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bier's block, also known as intravenous regional anesthesia, is a technique used for providing surgical anesthesia for short and superficial procedures on an extremity. This method involves the insertion of an intravenous catheter, application of a pneumatic tourniquet, and the administration of a local anesthetic into the isolated extremity.

 

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition pg 269 Morgan 7th 1906

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida is posted for LSCS under spinal anesthesia. 2.25 ml Inj. Hyperbaric bupivacaine 0.5% is given intrathecally. After the spinal anesthesia is administered, the nerve fibre to be blocked the latest is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A Alpha

 

Option A.

 

  • A Alpha fibers are the largest and most myelinated nerve fibers. They are responsible for carrying proprioceptive information related to muscle stretch and are associated with motor control.
  • A Alpha fibers are blocked the latest in spinal anesthesia because they are the most resistant to the effects of local anesthetics.

 

Explanation:

 

In spinal anesthesia, different types of nerve fibers are blocked at different rates of onset, with the largest and most myelinated fibers being blocked the latest.

 

Option B. A Beta: Beta fibers are also large myelinated fibers, but they are primarily responsible for transmitting sensory information related to touch and pressure.

 

Option C. A Delta: Delta fibers are smaller myelinated fibers that transmit sharp, fast-pain sensations. They are involved in the transmission of acute pain signals.

 

Option D. A Gamma: Gamma fibers are small, myelinated fibers that innervate muscle spindles and are involved in the regulation of muscle tone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In spinal anesthesia, the rate of onset of nerve fiber blockade follows a pattern where the largest and most myelinated nerve fibers, A Alpha fibers, are blocked the latest. These fibers are associated with proprioception and motor control.

 

Erlanger and Gasser Classification of Nerve Fibers:

 

 

Order of susceptibility of nerve fibers
To Local Anesthesia –

 

B > A Delta > A Gamma > A Beta > A Alpha > C

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 9th edition page 869,874.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is posted for lower limb debridement surgery under femoral and sciatic block. The drug used for blockade is 2% lignocaine with adrenaline. Addition of adrenaline to local anesthetic causes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decreased Absorption of LA

 

Explanation:

 

The addition of adrenaline (epinephrine) to a local anesthetic causes the following effect:

 

Option B.

 

  • Adrenaline, when added to a local anesthetic solution, acts as a vasoconstrictor.
  • Vasoconstrictors like adrenaline reduce the blood flow to the area where the local anesthetic is injected.
  • This decreased blood flow results in reduced absorption of the local anesthetic into the bloodstream, as it limits the rate at which the drug enters the systemic circulation.
  • As a result, the presence of adrenaline in the local anesthetic solution prolongs the duration of action and provides a more profound block, making the anesthesia more effective and longer lasting.
  • This vasoconstrictor action of adrenaline is particularly useful in regional anesthesia techniques like femoral and sciatic blocks, where it helps improve the depth and duration of anesthesia.
  • Vasoconstrictors should be used cautiously and are contraindicated in specific situations, such as injections close to end arteries (e.g., ring blocks of finger and toe digits), intravenous regional anesthesia (Bier's block)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The addition of adrenaline to a local anesthetic solution serves as a vasoconstrictor, leading to decreased absorption of the local anesthetic into the bloodstream.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition pg 269 Morgan 7th 489

choices.text: Increased Cardiac Output

questions.text: An 80-year-old female is posted for total hip replacement under spinal anesthesia. The consultant anaesthesiologist asks you to give lesser than normal dose of local anesthetic in the subarachnoid space. In which of these conditions do we not require dose modification of local anesthetics to prevent toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Increased Cardiac Output

 

Option D.

 

  • Increased cardiac output can lead to a more rapid systemic absorption and distribution of the local anesthetic.
  • This does not typically require a dose modification of the local anesthetic to prevent toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypercapnia:

 

  • Local anesthetics have a negative chronotropic (heart rate-reducing) and ionotropic (contractility-reducing) effect on the heart.
  • In the presence of hypercapnia (elevated CO2), the cardio-depressant effects of local anesthetics may be potentiated.
  • To prevent toxicity, it may be necessary to reduce the dose of local anesthetics in patients with hypercapnia.

 

Option B. Hypoxia:

 

  • Similar to hypercapnia, local anesthetics have negative chronotropic and ionotropic effects on the heart.
  • In the presence of hypoxia (low oxygen), the cardiodepressant effects of local anesthetics may be potentiated.
  • To prevent toxicity, it may be necessary to reduce the dose of local anesthetics in patients with hypoxia.

 

Option C. Old Age:

 

  • Age can influence the absorption, distribution, and metabolism of local anesthetics.
  • Older patients may require a lower dose of local anesthetic to achieve the desired effect due to potential alterations in drug pharmacokinetics.
  • Dose modification is often considered in elderly patients to prevent toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administering local anaesthetics for spinal anesthesia, various factors can influence the pharmacokinetics and potential toxicity of these drugs. While hypercapnia and hypoxia can potentiate the cardio depressant effects of local anaesthetics and may require dose modification to prevent toxicity, increased cardiac output does not directly potentiate these effects.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition pg 877,883, 896

questions.text: A patient is posted for shoulder dislocation repositioning surgery. The anesthetist gives a brachial plexus block with Chloroprocaine. Which of these is not true regarding chloroprocaine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Long Duration of Action

 

Option A.

 

  • Chloroprocaine is classified as a short-acting local anesthetic, not a long-acting one. Ester local anesthetics, including chloroprocaine, are known for their relatively short duration of action.
  • Chloroprocaine is an ester local anesthetic. Esters have a short duration of action.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Metabolized by Plasma Cholinesterase: Chloroprocaine, like other ester local anesthetics, is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase (also known as pseudocholinesterase).

 

Option C. High Incidence of Allergic Reactions: Chloroprocaine being an ester does have high allergical reaction tendency due to production of PABA (Para Amino Benzoic Acid) molecule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloroprocaine is an ester local anesthetic with a relatively short duration of action. It is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase and is generally associated with a lower incidence of allergic reactions compared to some other local anesthetics.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition pg 877,883, 896

questions.text: Carl Koller introduced cocaine eye drops for ophthalmic anesthesia 100 years ago. What is the enzyme that metabolizes cocaine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hepatic Carboxylesterase

 

Option C. This is the correct answer. Cocaine is an ester local anesthetic, and unlike other ester local anesthetics, it is primarily metabolized in the liver by hepatic carboxylesterase.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Plasma Esterase:

 

  • Plasma esterase refers to pseudocholinesterase or butyrylcholinesterase, which is the enzyme responsible for metabolizing most ester local anesthetics.
  • Cocaine, however, is an exception among ester local anesthetics and is not primarily metabolized by plasma esterase.

 

Option B. Butyrylcholinesterase:

 

  • Butyrylcholinesterase is another term for pseudocholinesterase, which is involved in the metabolism of ester local anesthetics but not cocaine.

 

Option D. Acetylcholinesterase:

 

  • Acetylcholinesterase is not involved in the metabolism of cocaine. It is an enzyme responsible for breaking down acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction and cholinergic synapses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine, introduced by Carl Koller for ophthalmic anesthesia, is a unique ester local anesthetic because it is not primarily metabolized by plasma esterase (pseudocholinesterase) like other ester local anesthetics. Instead, cocaine is metabolized in the liver by hepatic carboxylesterase.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anaesthesia 9th edition pg 875

questions.text: Which of these is not a high potency local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lignocaine

 

Explanation:

 

Local anesthetics vary in their potency, duration of action, and clinical use. While tetracaine, bupivacaine, and etidocaine are considered high-potency local anesthetics due to their potency and longer duration of action, lignocaine (lidocaine) falls into the intermediate-potency category.

 

  • Most Potent LA - Dibucaine
  • Least Potent LA - Procaine

 

Educational objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Millers Anaesthesia 8th edition pg 1031

questions.text:
Which statement(s) is/are accurate concerning local anesthetics?

 

  1. Prilocaine is Longer Acting than Bupivacaine.
  2. Tetracaine is more Potent than Lignocaine.
  3. Dibucaine is the Longest Acting Local Anesthetic.
  4. Bupivacaine can produce Cardiotoxicity.
  5. Cocaine can produce Hypotension.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

  • Prilocaine is Longer Acting than Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is known for its long duration of action, while prilocaine has a shorter duration of action compared to bupivacaine. Therefore, this statement is false.
  • Tetracaine is more Potent than Lignocaine: Tetracaine is considered a high-potency local anesthetic and is generally more potent than lignocaine (lidocaine), which is an intermediate-potency local anesthetic.
  • Dibucaine is the Longest-Acting Local Anesthetic: Dibucaine is known for its very long duration of action among local anesthetics, making it one of the longest-acting agents in this class.
  • Bupivacaine can produce Cardiotoxicity: Bupivacaine, particularly when used in high doses or inadvertently administered systemically, can produce cardiotoxicity, including potential for cardiac arrhythmias and toxicity.
  • Cocaine can produce Hypotension: Cocaine, as a vasoconstrictor, can lead to hypertension rather than hypotension due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on potency & duration local anaesthetics are classified into:

 

 

  • Cocaine causes vasoconstriction leading to hypertension.
  • Bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition pg 1031

choices.text: Voltage Dependent Block
Use Dependent Block.
Gradient Dependent Block

questions.text: The binding of local anaesthetics to open Na+ channels increase with the frequency of nerve depolarisation. This phenomenon is known as:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Use Dependent Block

 

Option B.

 

  • This is the correct answer.
  • Use-dependent block describes the phenomenon where the binding of local anesthetics to sodium channels increases with the frequency of nerve depolarization.
  • In other words, local anesthetics have a greater affinity for sodium channels in the open or inactivated state, especially when the nerve is firing rapidly.
  • Use-dependent block is important because it contributes to the preferential inhibition of rapidly firing nerves, such as those involved in pain transmission.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Voltage-Dependent Block:

 

  • Voltage-dependent block refers to the property of local anesthetics where their binding to sodium channels is influenced by the voltage (membrane potential) across the nerve cell membrane.
  • This term is related to the voltage-gated nature of sodium channels, which open and close in response to changes in membrane voltage.

 

Option C. Depolarizing Block:

 

  • Depolarizing block is a different concept related to neuromuscular blockade, where the muscle cell membrane remains depolarized (in a continuous state of excitation) due to the presence of a neuromuscular blocking agent like succinylcholine.

 

Option D. Gradient-Dependent Block:

 

  • This term is not commonly used in the context of local anesthetics and their mechanism of action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Use-dependent block, or phasic block, is a key concept in understanding the mechanism of action of local anesthetics. It refers to the increased binding of local anesthetics to sodium channels when the nerves are firing rapidly. This phenomenon plays a crucial role in preferentially inhibiting pain transmission by targeting nerves with high-frequency activity.

 

 

 Voltage - Gated Na channels exist in three stages - Resting, Open and Inactivated.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition pg 1046

questions.text: Identify the local anesthetics that carries out the reaction below after their administration?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Prilocaine

 

Option A. Prilocaine is known to cause methemoglobinemia when metabolized. Methemoglobinemia can result from the conversion of prilocaine to o-toluidine, which then leads to the formation of methemoglobin in the blood.

 

  • The above reaction is seen in Methemoglobinemia.
  • Underlying mechanism – conversion of iron in haemoglobin from the ferrous [Fe2+] to the ferric [Fe3+] form

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is an amide local anesthetic, and it is not typically associated with methemoglobinemia. Methemoglobinemia is more commonly linked to certain ester local anesthetics, like prilocaine.

 

Option C. Tetracaine: Tetracaine is an ester local anesthetic, but it is not primarily known for causing methemoglobinemia. Prilocaine is a more recognized culprit in this regard.

 

Option D. Cocaine: Cocaine, when used medically in topical solutions, can lead to local vasoconstriction and tissue damage but is not directly associated with methemoglobinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prilocaine is an ester local anesthetic that can lead to methemoglobinemia as a side effect. This condition can manifest with symptoms such as cyanosis, headache, shortness of breath, and poor muscle coordination.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition pg 1048-1050

questions.text: Find the incorrect pair of local anesthetic and its pKa value?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lignocaine – 8.3

 

Explanation:

 

pKa of Lignocaine is 7.8

 

  • pKa of a drug is the pH at which the drug is 50% ionized and 50% non-ionized.
  • Unionized form of local anesthetics penetrates the lipid soluble membranes and acts quickly. More the unionized form faster the onset of action. Hence, pKa correlates with the onset of action.
  • Local anesthetics with a pKa closest to physiological pH will have (at physiological pH) a greater fraction of nonionized base that more readily permeates the nerve cell membrane, generally facilitating a more rapid onset of action. It is the lipid-soluble free-base form that more readily diffuses across the neural sheath (epineurium) and through the nerve membrane.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition pg 486

questions.text: A patient is posted for trigger thumb release. It is a 30-minute procedure, and the anaesthesiologist decides to do it under Bier’s block. Which of these is the most common local anaesthetic used for Bier’s block?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lignocaine

 

Option B.

 

  • Lignocaine (lidocaine) is the most commonly used local anesthetic for Bier's block, also known as Intravenous Regional Anesthesia (IVRA). It is preferred because of its short duration of action and lower risk of local anesthesia systemic toxicity.
  • Lignocaine is the most commonly used drug for Bier’s block (intravenous regional anesthesia).
  • Lignocaine is preferred as it has short duration of action and less incidence of local anesthesia systemic toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is not the most common choice for Bier's block. While it is a local anesthetic used in various regional anesthesia techniques, it is typically avoided for Bier's block due to concerns about its longer duration of action and potential cardiotoxicity.

 

Option C. Ropivacaine: Ropivacaine is another amide local anesthetic like bupivacaine. It is not the most common choice for Bier's block due to its longer duration of action and similarity to bupivacaine in terms of potential cardiotoxicity.

 

Option D. Levobupivacaine: Levobupivacaine is the levorotatory enantiomer of bupivacaine. It shares some characteristics with bupivacaine, including potential cardiotoxicity, and is not typically the first choice for Bier's block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lignocaine (lidocaine) is the preferred local anesthetic for Bier's block or intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA). Its short duration of action and lower risk of local anesthesia systemic toxicity make it a suitable choice for this technique, which is commonly used for short-duration procedures on the extremities.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition pg 878

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. She states that she has an allergy to local anesthetics. Upon further questioning, she states that she received procaine at the dentist and her “heart began to race, and she became light-headed.” Which of the following conditions most likely explains this patient’s reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A Side Effect of Epinephrine, which was added to the Novocain Preparation.

 

Option C. This is the correct answer. Epinephrine is commonly added to local anesthetic preparations to prolong the duration of action and reduce systemic absorption of the local anesthetic. Epinephrine can cause sympathetic responses such as tachycardia, which may explain the patient's racing heart and feeling light-headed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A true Allergic Reaction to the Amide Local Anesthetic Procaine: Procaine is an ester local anesthetic, not an amide. Ester local anesthetics are more likely to cause allergic reactions due to the formation of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) during their breakdown.

 

Option B. An Allergic Reaction to a Breakdown Product of Procaine: The patient’s symptoms of tachycardia are more consistent with the sympathetic sequelae from epinephrine injection rather than a true allergic reaction which would also have bronchospasm and urticaria.

 

Option D. A Somatization of the patient’s Apprehension toward Dental Procedures: While anxiety can lead to physiological responses like increased heart rate and light-headedness, it is less likely to explain the specific symptoms described by the patient, especially in the context of dental procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients receiving local anesthetics may experience side effects, which can sometimes be attributed to additives like epinephrine used to enhance the anesthetic's effectiveness.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesiology 7th edition pg 478

choices.text: Increased Duration of Action
Increased Potency of Blockade
Increased Peak Plasma Concentration of Local Anesthetic
Marker for Accidental Intravascular Injection

questions.text: Which of these is not an advantage of vasoconstrictors when added to local anesthetic solutions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Increased Peak Plasma Concentration of Local Anesthetic

 

Option C. This statement is not correct. The addition of vasoconstrictors like adrenaline to local anesthetic solutions does not increase the peak plasma concentration of the local anesthetic. Instead, it reduces the peak plasma concentration by slowing down the systemic absorption of the drug. This reduction in peak plasma concentration is a safety advantage, as it decreases the risk of local anesthesia systemic toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased Duration of Action: This is an advantage of vasoconstrictors when added to local anesthetic solutions. Vasoconstrictors like adrenaline (epinephrine) can constrict blood vessels at the injection site, which reduces the rate of systemic absorption of the local anesthetic. This prolongs the duration of action of the anesthetic, making it effective for a longer period.

 

Option B. Increased Potency of Blockade: This is also an advantage of vasoconstrictors. Vasoconstrictors not only prolong the duration of action but can also enhance the potency of the local blockade by concentrating the anesthetic at the site of action, leading to more profound anesthesia.

 

Option D. Marker for Accidental Intravascular Injection: This is another advantage of vasoconstrictors. If a vasoconstrictor like adrenaline is accidentally injected into a blood vessel (Intravascular Injection), it can lead to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure, serving as a marker for the inadvertent injection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The addition of vasoconstrictors to local anesthetic solutions provides several advantages, including increased duration of action, increased potency of blockade, and serving as a marker for accidental intravascular injection. However, it does not increase the peak plasma concentration of the local anesthetic; instead, it reduces it, which is important for minimizing the risk of local anesthesia systemic toxicity.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition pg 1040

questions.text: A 27-year-old female who came with the following complaints after sunbathing at the beach for one day. Topical anaesthetic was prescribed for the treatment of this condition. Which topical anesthetic will not be helpful in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cocaine

 

Option C. Cocaine is not helpful in the treatment of sunburn. Unlike other local anaesthetics, cocaine is a vasoconstrictor, meaning it constricts blood vessels. This vasoconstrictive effect can reduce blood flow to the affected area, potentially making sunburn symptoms worse rather than providing relief.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Etidocaine: Etidocaine is a local anaesthetic, and like other local anaesthetics, it has vasodilatory properties. Vasodilation can be helpful in the treatment of sunburn as it may help reduce inflammation and discomfort.

 

Option B. Lignocaine (Lidocaine): Lignocaine, also known as lidocaine, is a local anaesthetic with vasodilatory properties. It can be used topically to relieve discomfort associated with sunburn by reducing inflammation and pain.

 

Option D. Articaine: Articaine, like other local anesthetics, has vasodilatory properties and can be helpful in relieving discomfort associated with sunburn.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sunburn is a condition characterized by skin inflammation and discomfort due to excessive sun exposure. Topical local anesthetics can be used to relieve the pain and discomfort associated with sunburn by their vasodilatory effects, which can reduce inflammation and provide relief. It's essential to choose local anesthetics with vasodilatory properties, like etidocaine, lignocaine, or articaine, rather than vasoconstrictors like cocaine, which can exacerbate sunburn symptoms.

 

 

Ref: Stoelting's Pharmacology and Physiology in Anesthesia Practice, 5th Edition, Page no 885

questions.text: A patient who underwent haemorrhoidectomy under spinal anesthesia starts complaining of weakness, paralysis, numbness, and tingling in both legs post-operatively. These symptoms are most commonly seen after which administration of which local anaesthetic?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lignocaine

 

Option B. Lidocaine is a local anesthetic used in spinal anesthesia, and it has been reported to have a Higher incidence of causing Transient Neurological Symptoms (TNS). TNS can manifest as weakness, paralysis, numbness, and tingling in the Lower Extremities. While the exact mechanism is not fully understood, it is a well-documented side effect associated with Lidocaine in Spinal Anesthesia. Symptoms develop within a few hours and up to 24 hours after spinal anesthesia. Symptoms typically do not last beyond 2 days.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is a Long-Acting Local anesthetic commonly used in Spinal Anesthesia. It is less frequently associated with TNS compared to Lidocaine.

 

Option C. Ropivacaine: Ropivacaine is another Local Anesthetic used in Spinal Anesthesia. It has a lower risk of causing TNS compared to Lidocaine.

 

Option D. Prilocaine: Prilocaine is less commonly used in spinal anesthesia. Its association with TNS is relatively lower compared to lidocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transient Neurological Symptoms (TNS) can occur after spinal anesthesia and manifest as pain, weakness, paralysis, numbness, or tingling in the lower extremities. While TNS can potentially be caused by various local anesthetics, lidocaine (lignocaine) is particularly associated with a higher incidence of this side effect.

 

 

Ref: https://www.openanesthesia.org/local_anesthetic_transient_neurologic_symptoms/

choices.text: Prolongs Duration of Action
Reduces Systemic Toxicity.
Improves Depth of Anesthesia
Potentiates the Action of GA like Isoflurane

questions.text: All of the following are advantages of adding adrenaline with local anesthetics except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Potentiates the Action of GA like Isoflurane

 

Option D. This statement is incorrect. Adrenaline added to local anesthetics primarily acts at the site of injection, and its effects are more localized. It does not significantly potentiate the action of general anesthetics like isoflurane, which primarily work through central mechanisms in the brain. Adrenaline's primary role is to enhance the effectiveness and safety of local anesthesia.

 

Explanation:

 

Adrenaline concentration as vasoconstrictor - 1:2,00,000

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Prolongs Duration of Action: Adrenaline added to local anesthetics can prolong the duration of action by constricting blood vessels near the injection site. This constriction reduces the rate of systemic absorption of the local anesthetic, leading to a longer-lasting block of sensation in the targeted area.

 

Option B. Reduces Systemic Toxicity: Adrenaline helps reduce the systemic toxicity of local anesthetics by limiting their absorption into the bloodstream. This vasoconstrictor effect decreases the peak plasma concentration of the local anesthetic, lowering the risk of systemic side effects or toxicity.

 

Option C. Improves Depth of Anesthesia: Adding adrenaline to local anesthetics enhances the depth and quality of anesthesia. The vasoconstriction it produces enhances the spread and depth of the local anesthetic effect, ensuring more effective pain relief and anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenaline (epinephrine) is commonly added to local anesthetics for several advantages, including prolonging the duration of action, reducing systemic toxicity, and improving the depth and quality of anesthesia. However, it does not significantly potentiate the action of general anesthetics like isoflurane, which primarily act through central mechanisms in the brain.

 

 

Ref: Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition • Page no 414

questions.text: A first year anesthesia resident is giving axillary block by landmark guided technique. She accidentally punctures the axillary artery during the process and injects 20 ml of local anesthetic intravascularly. The patient starts getting seizures bradyarrythmias and severe hypotension within 5 minutes of this injection. What should be the treatment of this condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 20% Intralipid

 

  • This is a case of Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity (LAST).
  • Drug of choice for treatment of Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity is 20% Lipid emulsion therapy at 1.5ml/kg.

 

Option C. 20% Intralipid is the drug of choice for treating LAST. It works by creating a lipid sink, where the lipophilic local anesthetic molecules are sequestered in the lipid phase, reducing their toxic effects. This can rapidly reverse the symptoms of LAST, including seizures, bradyarrhythmias, and hypotension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dantrolene Sodium: Dantrolene Sodium is a medication used to treat malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option B. 10% Intralipid: Intralipid, a Lipid Emulsion, is used to treat LAST. However, 10% Intralipid is less concentrated than 20% Intralipid and may be less effective in rapidly reversing the toxic effects of intravascular local anesthetic injection.

 

Option D. Vasopressin: Vasopressin can help in treating hypotension, but it has no role in LAST.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity (LAST) can occur when local anesthetics are inadvertently injected intravascularly. The most effective treatment for LAST is the administration of 20% Intralipid, a lipid emulsion, which acts as a lipid sink to sequester and reduce the toxic effects of local anesthetics. Early recognition and prompt administration of 20% Intralipid can reverse the symptoms of LAST and prevent serious complications.

 

Drug of choice - 20% Lipid emulsion therapy at 1.5ml/kg

 

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 8th edition • Page no: 1048-1050

questions.text: As per the susceptibility of nerve fibres to local anaesthetics, which of the statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C Fibers are more susceptible than B Fibers

 

Explanation:

 

Order of Susceptibility of Nerve Fibers to Local Anesthetics

 

Option A. Smaller Fibers>>> susceptible than Larger Fibers

 

Option C. Myelinated Fibers are more susceptible than unmyelinated fibers

 

Option D. B > A Gamma> A Delta> A Beta> A Alpha> C Fibers

 

Educational Objective 

The order of susceptibility of nerve fibers to local anesthetics is as follows: B Fibers > A Gamma Fibers > A Delta Fibers > A Beta Fibers > A Alpha Fibers > C fibers, with smaller diameter fibers generally being more susceptible than larger diameter fibers and myelinated fibers being more susceptible than unmyelinated fibers.

 

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition • Page no: 869, 1417 Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesiology 5th edition pg 265

choices.text: In acts on Sodium Channels in both Active and Inactive State
It is the most Cardiotoxic Local Anesthetic.
It is given intravenously in cardiac arrhythmias.
It is Contraindicated in Malignant Hyperthermia.

questions.text: All are true about Lignocaine except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is the most Cardiotoxic Local Anesthetic.

 

Option B. Lignocaine is not the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic. In fact, it is considered one of the less cardiotoxic local anesthetics. Bupivacaine is an example of a local anesthetic with a higher risk of cardiotoxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It acts on Sodium Channels in both Active and Inactive State: Lignocaine acts on sodium channels in both the active (open) and inactive (closed) states.

 

Option C. It is given Intravenously in Cardiac Arrhythmias: Lignocaine is administered intravenously to treat ventricular arrhythmias and prevent ventricular fibrillation.

 

Option D. It is contraindicated in Malignant Hyperthermia: Lignocaine is contraindicated in patients with malignant hyperthermia, a rare but life-threatening condition that can be triggered by certain medications, including some anesthetics.

Educational Objective:

 

Lignocaine (Lidocaine) is a local anesthetic that acts on sodium channels in both active and inactive states. It is used intravenously to treat cardiac arrhythmias but is contraindicated in patients with malignant hyperthermia. Contrary to the statement in option B, Lignocaine is not the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic; other local anesthetics, such as Bupivacaine, have a higher risk of cardiotoxicity.

 

Most cardiotoxic agent is Bupivacaine.

questions.text: An ophthalmologist wants to examine a 10-year-old child with an irritating sensation in the eye. Which of these is local anesthetics is commonly used as a part of topical ophthalmic eye drops?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Proparacaine

 

Option A:

 

  • Proparacaine is a topical ophthalmic anesthetic agent commonly used by ophthalmologists for procedures such as eye examinations, foreign body removal, or minor eye surgeries.
  • It has a rapid onset of action, typically within 2 minutes, and provides effective local anesthesia for approximately 20 minutes, making it suitable for short ophthalmic procedures.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option B. Cocaine: Cocaine is an older anesthetic agent and is not commonly used in modern ophthalmology due to its potential for abuse and addiction.

 

Option C. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic commonly used for regional anesthesia and nerve blocks, but it is not typically used as a topical ophthalmic anesthetic.

 

Option D. Mepivacaine: Mepivacaine is another local anesthetic primarily used for dental and regional anesthesia and is not commonly used in ophthalmic applications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proparacaine (0.5%) and Tetracaine (0.5%) are commonly used topical ophthalmic anesthetic agents for providing short-term local anesthesia during eye examinations or minor eye procedures. Ophthalmologists often use these agents to ensure patient comfort during these procedures.

 

Commonly used eye drops in ophthalmic solutions is:

 

Proparacaine (0.5%) and Tetracaine (0.5%)
Duration of action of Proparacaine is 20 minutes. Onset of its action is within 2 minutes.

 

 

Ref: Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition • Page no 413

questions.text: In a patient planned for labour analgesia, what is the maximum dose of plain bupivacaine that can be given, if the patient’s weight is 80 kg and height is 160cm?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 200 mg

 

Maximum dose of Bupivacaine to be used is 2.5 mg/kg. Thus, in an 80 kg individual the dose will be 80 x 2.5 = 200mg. 

 

Educational Objective 

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesiology 5th edition pg 272

choices.text: It is Less Cardiotoxic as compared to Racemic Bupivacaine.
It is Less Potent as compared to Racemic Bupivacaine.
It is Less Neurotoxic as compared to Racemic Bupivacaine.
It causes Less Myocardial Depression as compared to Racemic Bupivacaine.

questions.text: A patient with history of ischemic heart disease is posted for foot surgery under sciatic nerve block. The resident asks if he should use levobupivacaine instead of bupivacaine in this patient. Which of these is not true regarding levobupivacaine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is less potent as compared to racemic bupivacaine.

 

Option B. Levobupivacaine is equally potent as compared to racemic bupivacaine. Both levobupivacaine and racemic bupivacaine have similar local anesthetic potency.

 

Option A. It is Less Cardiotoxic as compared to Racemic Bupivacaine: Levobupivacaine is the pure S-enantiomer of racemic bupivacaine. It is known to be less cardiotoxic than the racemic mixture of bupivacaine, as it has a lower propensity to cause cardiac toxicity, particularly in terms of slowing the heart rate and conduction disturbances.

 

Option C. It is less Less Neurotoxic as compared to Racemic Bupivacaine: Levobupivacaine is considered to be less neurotoxic than racemic bupivacaine. Neurotoxicity is a concern with local anesthetics, and levobupivacaine is preferred in situations where a lower risk of neurotoxicity is desired.

 

Option D. It causes Less Myocardial Depression as compared to Racemic Bupivacaine: Levobupivacaine is known to cause less depression of myocardial contractility compared to racemic bupivacaine. This property makes it suitable for use in patients with a history of cardiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levobupivacaine is the S-enantiomer of racemic bupivacaine. It is less cardiotoxic and less neurotoxic than racemic bupivacaine. Contrary to Option B, levobupivacaine is not less potent; it has comparable local anesthetic potency to racemic bupivacaine

 

 

Ref: Glaser C, Marhofer P, Zimpfer G, Heinz MT, Sitzwohl C, Kapral S, Schindler I. Levobupivacaine versus racemic bupivacaine for spinal anesthesia. AnesthAnalg. 2002 Jan;94(1):194-8, table of contents. doi: 10.1097/00000539-200201000-00037. PMID: 11772827.
